main event: Multiple civilian witnesses reported seeing unusual lights and objects in the sky over southern Michigan in March 1966.
interesting points: The lights were associated with swamp areas and were described as glowing, reddish-yellow, and green in color.
The motion of the lights was reported as smooth and slow, with a tendency to disappear suddenly and reappear elsewhere.
Investigators could not find any consistent evidence of physical objects, and concluded the sightings were likely caused by natural phenomena like marsh gas.
Some witnesses claimed to see more distinct objects, but the investigator found their descriptions unreliable due to lack of technical expertise.
The investigator had difficulty thoroughly investigating all the reports due to the large number of witnesses and media attention surrounding the incidents.
location: southern Michigan, including Dexter and Hillsdale areas
witnesses: multiple civilian witnesses, some with technical backgrounds
photographs: no, the report does not mention any photographs
